entry.title: Exploring the SAP Signavio Process Manager API Part 2: Reading Directories and Process Diagrams
entry.content:
ðŸ‘‰Read Part 1: Getting Started with SAP Signavio Process Manager API

 

Intro

In the first post of this series, we looked at how to get started with the SAP Signavio Process Manager API. Once you start working with the API, a number of practical use cases open up, such as: 

  • Custom reporting on processes, diagrams, or tasks, for example to track ownership, changes, or completeness 
  • Replicating processes and relationships to external tools such as GRC systems, data catalogs, or Enterprise Architecture Management tools 
  • Extending SAP Signavio Process Manager functionality through API-based integrations, for example for translations or automated documentation. 

All of these scenarios start with the same foundation: Being able to read your workspace structure and access process diagrams programmatically.

 

In this post, weâ€™ll: 
  • Read the structure of your workspace 
  • Navigate through folders and subfolders 
  • List process diagrams and their key attributes (title, created, updated, ID, folder) 
  • Export diagrams as PNG files and JSON to access attributes from the BPMN model 

 

With the help of the following APIs: 
  • Directory API to explore folders and list diagrams (SAP Business Accelerator Hub (SAP BAH), SAP Help) 
  • Model API to access model details (SAP BAH, SAP Help) 
  • Import and Export API to export diagrams as PNG and JSON files (SAP BAH, SAP Help) 

By the end, youâ€™ll have everything you need to generate a simple inventory of your workspace, along with a visual snapshot or a JSON representation of each diagram. 

 

Understanding the Directory API

If youâ€™ve ever opened the Explorer in SAP Signavio Process Manager, you know the basic structure:

  • Shared Documents,
  • My Documents,
  • Trash,
  • Dictionary / Glossary 

SPM

The Directory API gives you the same structure in JSON. Itâ€™s the starting point for everything else and the endpoints follow the same base scheme: 

ðŸ‘‰https://{baseUrl}/spm/v1/directory 

 

Note: Base URL depends on your region (find the regions here). For a complete and up-to-date overview of all endpoints and parameters, refer to the SAP Signavio Process Manager API Guide and the API documentation on SAP BAH.

Every request needs: 

  • x-signavio-id: your JWT authentication token 
  • Cookie: JSESSIONID={jsessionId}:  the session cookie from the auth response 
  • Accept: application/json

You can find a step-by-step Guide on authentication in this blog post. 

Note: If those headers are missing or wrong, youâ€™ll fairly quickly run into 403 or 423 errors, especially if SSO is enforced and the technical user isnâ€™t set up correctly. Learn more on SAP Help.

 

Retrieving the Root Folders

Letâ€™s start with the top level. 

ðŸ‘‰GET /spm/v1/directory 

This returns a list of resources, usually three folders plus one dictionary entry: 

  • rel: "dir" with type: "public" â†’ Shared Documents 
  • rel: "dir" with type: "private" â†’ My Documents 
  • rel: "dir" with type: "trash" â†’ Trash 
  • rel: "glos" â†’ link to the Dictionary 

 

A few things to note: 
  • The folder ID is hidden inside href (/directory/{id}) 
  • Type differentiates public/private/trash only at root level 
  • You already get metadata like name, created, visible, deleted 

To explore whatâ€™s inside these folders, the Directory API provides href references that point to the next level of the folder structure. 

 

Navigating Folders and Reading Their Contents 

To explore whatâ€™s inside a folder, call: 

ðŸ‘‰GET /spm/v1/directory/{id} 

This returns a JSON array with several different rel types, such as: 

  • rel: "info" â†’ metadata about this folder 
  • rel: "parents" â†’ all ancestor folders 
  • rel: "dir" â†’ subfolders 
  • rel: "mod" â†’ diagrams contained in this folder 

... and more.

 

Two key object types for us: 
  • Subfolder: rel:"dir" â†’ follow href (/directory/{id}) to go deeper 
  • Diagram: rel:"mod" â†’ href contains the diagram ID (/model/{id}), and rep contains useful attributes 

You can build a complete view of your folder tree and collect all diagrams along the way using only the Directory API. 

 

How to collect all diagram IDs from the workspace 

At this point, you might be thinking: thatâ€™s great, but my workspace has dozens or hundreds of diagrams. I donâ€™t want to manually follow each folder and copy every ID one by one. 

This is where a recursive traversal comes in. Since folders can be nested arbitrarily deep, your script starts at the root folders, follows every rel = "dir"  entry, and calls GET /directory/{id} for each subfolder. This step is repeated until no further subfolders are found. Diagrams (rel = "mod") can be collected at each level during this traversal. 

This recursive logic is straightforward to implement in a script and allows you to reliably discover all folders and diagrams, regardless of how deeply they are nested. 

 

Reading Diagram Metadata from the Directory API 

 For many reporting scenarios, you donâ€™t need a dedicated â€œdiagram APIâ€ to read attributes like title, created date, or folder. For a lightweight â€œlandscape reportâ€, you can map entries returned by the Directory API like this: 

  • Diagram ID â†’ "href", for example /model/fea8a2ac6d184bf2852ecbaa11622a51 (last part) 
  • Title â†’ "name" 
  • Created â†’ "created" 
  • Last updated â†’ "updated" 
  • Diagram type â†’ "type" (for example BPMN, process map, DMN) 
  • Folder â†’ "parentName" and "parent" 
  • Description â†’ "description" (if maintained) 

For many scenarios, this level of metadata is enough. But as soon as you want to understand relationships between elements, work with custom attributes, inspect BPMN content and shapes, or generate visual representations of diagrams (such as PNG exports), you need access to the model itself. Thatâ€™s where the next step comes in. 

 

Accessing Model Content and Exporting Visual Representations (JSON, PNG) 

Once you have a list of diagrams and their IDs, the next step is often to retrieve the actual model content or a visual representation of the diagram.

You can export the latest revision of a diagram in different formats (see the API documentation and SAP BAH for the complete list), for example: 

  • PNG â†’ Useful if you need a visual snapshot of the diagram, for example for documentation or reports. 

ðŸ‘‰GET /spm/v1/model/{id}/png   

 

  • JSON  â†’  Useful if you want to access the underlying model content, including elements (for example BPMN shapes such as tasks) and custom attributes. 

ðŸ‘‰GET /spm/v1/model/{id}/json

 

In future blog posts, weâ€™ll explore how to extract specific attributes and relationships directly from the process model using the JSON export.â€¯ 

 

Common Pitfalls and Tips 

 

Token validity and authentication 

  • The token stays valid for 8 hours. After that, you simply repeat the same request to get a fresh one. You can find more details in SAP Help. 
  • Using a technical user with the API Edition license helps avoid SSO-related redirects and ensures API access without consuming UI licenses. For more information on access and licensing, view SAP Help. 

And if you want a quick refresher, Iâ€™ve also walked through the steps in the first blog post. 

Permissions and HTTP errors 

  • 403 (Forbidden) usually means â€œaccess deniedâ€. The user doesnâ€™t have permission to open that folder or diagram. Double-check workspace access rights and assigned roles. 
  • 404 (Not Found) means the referenced folder or diagram doesnâ€™t exist, or it isnâ€™t accessible in the current workspace. 
  • Responses like redirects or 423 errors are often caused by missing or incorrect headers. Make sure your requests explicitly include Accept: application/json and that youâ€™re using the correct authentication setup, as described in the API documentation. 

Performance and rate limits 

The APIs enforce rate limits to protect the system.  At the time of writing, the following limit applies: 

  • Rate limit: up to 50 requests per 60 seconds
âš ï¸ Note: Since this limit may change over time, always refer to the official API documentation for the most up-to-date values.

 

Best Practices

When working with larger workspaces, itâ€™s important not to send too many API requests too quickly. For example, looping through hundreds of folders or diagrams with one request right after another can hit rate or concurrency limits faster than youâ€™d expect. 

To keep things running smoothly, these best practices can help: 

  • Reuse results where possible 
    If you run scripts repeatedly, save folder IDs or previous responses and reuse them, instead of loading the whole workspace again every time. 
  • Slow down large request runs 
    When exporting or analyzing many diagrams, add small pauses between calls or process items in smaller batches rather than all at once. 

If your workspace is very large, it can also help to narrow down what you scan: 

  • Start from specific root folders 
    For example, begin with one business area instead of searching through the entire workspace. 
  • Use naming conventions or folder structures 
    This makes it easier to focus only on the relevant parts and skip everything you donâ€™t need. 

â€¯ 

Wrapping Up  

ðŸ’¡In this post, we focused on understanding what is actually stored in an SAP Signavio Process Manager workspace and how to access it via API. By combining the APIs , you can traverse folders, list diagrams, extract metadata, and retrieve both visual and structured representations of your processes. This provides a reliable basis for building inventories, reports, or integrations that need an up-to-date view of your process landscape. 

â­In a follow-up post, weâ€™ll take a closer look at how to extract specific attributes and relationships directly from the process model using the JSON representation. Stay tuned! 

You have questions or feedback? Contact Us!

ðŸ“« signavio_ecosystem@sap.com
